questions.question: By default, variables in Rust are...
questions.explanation: In Rust, variables are immutable by default to encourage safety and predictability.

questions.question: Which keyword is used to make a variable mutable?
questions.explanation: Adding 'mut' after 'let' makes a variable mutable.

questions.question: What is true about constants in Rust?

options.text: Their type must be explicitly annotated
They can only be declared inside functions

questions.explanation: Unlike variables where types can often be inferred, constants always require an explicit type annotation.

questions.question: What is 'shadowing' in Rust?

options.text: Hiding a variable so it cannot be used
Declaring a new variable with the same name as a previous one
Copying a variable to a different memory location
An error that occurs when two variables have the same name

questions.explanation: Shadowing allows you to reuse a name for a new variable, potentially with a different type.

questions.question: What happens if you try to change the type of a 'mut' variable?

options.text: The value is cast to the new type

questions.explanation: Mutable variables allow you to change the value, but the type must remain the same as when it was initialized.
